citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two nursing female dogs and one puppy were underweight.
**Black and White Adult Female Poodle (microchip number 900215002579390) had loosely formed stools present in the
enclosure. When the inspector examined the dog, her spine and hips were easily felt under the haircoat. She is nursing 5
puppies born 27-July-2022. The facility representative states the dog is being fed canned food but has not identified this
dog as underweight in medical records or have a record of when canned food was given. This dog has not been
evaluated by a veterinarian for the poor body condition or the loose stool.
**Dapple Adult Female Poodle (microchip number 990000003112321) had loosely formed stools present in the enclosure.
When the inspector examined the dog, her spine, ribs and hips were easily felt under the hair coat with little to no fat or
muscle covering the dog's frame. She is nursing 5 puppies born 20-July-2022. The facility representative was not aware
of this dog's body condition, the dog has not been evaluated by a veterinarian for the poor body condition or the loose
stool.
**A male Bernedoodle/Poodle puppy born 20-July-2022, litter 35, was underweight when the inspector examined him. The
ribs and spine were easily felt under the haircoat with little to no fat or muscle covering. The facility representative was not
aware of this puppy's body condition, the puppy has not been evaluated by a veterinarian for the poor body condition.
An emaciated or underweight body condition could indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in
the death of the animal.
The above mentioned dogs must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an
effective treatment plan in writing. This treatment plan must be made available for APHIS inspection.
To be corrected by: The facility representative and licensee were verbally told these dogs needed to be evaluated by a
veterinarian by noon (12PM) 13-September-2022.

Two approximate 16 week old Bernedoodles had no official identification. For official identification, the facility uses cage
cards for puppies under 16 weeks or microchips placed under the skin for dogs over 16 weeks of age, these two dogs had
neither form of official identification. An acceptable form of official identification (listed below) is necessary for APHIS
officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly trace their movements.
All live dogs over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by
a legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, by a microchip placed under the dog’s skin or if under 16 weeks of
age a cage card may be used for official identification. The licensee must place a microchip under the dog’s skin of the 2
dogs listed above or apply one of the other forms of identification. The licensee must ensure that all dogs have the correct
type of official form of identification at all times.
To be corrected by: 23-September-2022.

The licensee documents the acquisition information for the adult dogs on APHIS 7005 (Record of Acquisition for Dogs).
Only 4 adult dogs are listed on the form and the inspector counted 91 adult dogs during the inspection. Acquisition
information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals during inspection and to properly
trace their movements.
The licensee documents the acquisition information for puppies born at the facility on a cage card. Two litters of puppies
had not been updated on the cage cards when the puppies were sold. Litter 31- 3 Goldendoodle puppies were sold but
not marked on the cage card. Litter 22- 1 Bernedoodle puppy was sold but not marked on the cage card. Acquisition
records of animals born at the premises must be accurate and kept up to date to ensure proper identification and allow
APHIS officials to track the animal's movement.
The facility shall make, keep, and maintain an approved method of documentation which fully and correctly disclose all
information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or
under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The facility
must ensure all required acquisition information for each dog is properly and accurately documented at all times.
To be corrected by: 19-September-2022.

There are 3 outdoor enclosures housing a total of 12 adult dogs where the dogs have dug large holes under flooring
structures. 2 enclosures, the holes were dug under cement hog slat flooring and 1 enclosure had a hole dug below plastic
flooring. The holes were large enough for the large breed dogs to fit their head and front legs below the flooring. Holes
dug beneath flooring at severe angles into the ground could cause injury or even the death of a dog should the flooring
collapse into the holes.
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in
good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from
entering. The facility must eliminate the holes dug in the enclosure to ensure the safety of the dogs.
To be corrected by: 19-September-2022.

At least 11 enclosures housing 44 adult dogs had significant buildup of cobwebs in their outdoor shelter. The facility
representative stated these cobwebs were not present last week when he cleaned. The cobwebs were present in all 4
corners of the shelters and at least 3 enclosures had cobwebs present in the top of the self feeder. Many cobwebs were
still active with spiders present and dead insects in the webs.
All surfaces of housing facilities must be cleaned and sanitized when necessary to satisfy generally accepted husbandry
standards and practices to support the health of the dogs. The facility must clean and sanitize surfaces in the outdoor
shelters on a schedule that prevents the buildup of cobwebs and pests (spiders and other insects).
To be corrected by: 20-September-2022.

The inspector observed 4 adult poodles running loose on the property. The facility representative was unaware of the
dogs being out of their outdoor enclosure. They stated they have had some people dumping dogs on their property
recently. When the inspector and facility representative went outside, the dogs were identified as the facility's dogs and he
knew which pen they were from. All dogs went back into their enclosure at the time of inspection. The clips holding the
gate to the enclosure seemed to have failed to hold the gate closed causing their escape.
A primary enclosure must contain the dogs securely to ensure they are protected from various possible injuries. The
facility must ensure that all enclosures contain the dogs at all times.
To be corrected by: This day forward.

At least 3 outdoor enclosures housing a total of 14 adult dogs had caked dog kibble present in the self feeder. The
accumulation of caked food in the corners of the feeder tray was scraped away with the inspector's finger nail. One
enclosure housing 4 adult dogs had cobwebs with dead insects present in the top of the self feeder and a beetle was
found in the tray in a chunk of kibble and dog hair. Dog food that is caked, deteriorating and/or contaminated by insects is
not considered wholesome and palatable and may lead to reduced feed consumption, poor nutrition and poor body
condition.
Food must be uncontaminated, wholesome, palatable, and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain the normal
condition and weight of the dog. The licensee must remove all contaminated, caked, and deteriorating food from the self-
feeders and ensure that all food remains uncontaminated and of good quality at all times.
To be corrected by: 19-September-2022.
This inspection was conducted with a facility representative and the exit interview was conducted with the licensee and
facility representative.
The licensee cancelled his USDA license in writing effective immediately during the exit interview.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two nursing female dogs and one puppy were underweight. 
**Black and White Adult Female Poodle (microchip number 900215002579390) had loosely formed stools present in the 
enclosure. When the inspector examined the dog, her spine and hips were easily felt under the haircoat. She is nursing 5 
puppies born 27-July-2022. The facility representative states the dog is being fed canned food but has not identified this 
dog as underweight in medical records or have a record of when canned food was given. This dog has not been 
evaluated by a veterinarian for the poor body condition or the loose stool. 
**Dapple Adult Female Poodle (microchip number 990000003112321) had loosely formed stools present in the enclosure. 
When the inspector examined the dog, her spine, ribs and hips were easily felt under the hair coat with little to no fat or 
muscle covering the dog's frame. She is nursing 5 puppies born 20-July-2022. The facility representative was not aware 
of this dog's body condition, the dog has not been evaluated by a veterinarian for the poor body condition or the loose 
stool. 
**A male Bernedoodle/Poodle puppy born 20-July-2022, litter 35, was underweight when the inspector examined him. The 
ribs and spine were easily felt under the haircoat with little to no fat or muscle covering. The facility representative was not 
aware of this puppy's body condition, the puppy has not been evaluated by a veterinarian for the poor body condition. 
An emaciated or underweight body condition could indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in

the death of the animal. 
The above mentioned dogs must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an 
effective treatment plan in writing. This treatment plan must be made available for APHIS inspection. 
To be corrected by: The facility representative and licensee were verbally told these dogs needed to be evaluated by a 
veterinarian by noon (12PM) 13-September-2022. 
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
Two approximate 16 week old Bernedoodles had no official identification. For official identification, the facility uses cage 
cards for puppies under 16 weeks or microchips placed under the skin for dogs over 16 weeks of age, these two dogs had 
neither form of official identification. An acceptable form of official identification (listed below) is necessary for APHIS 
officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly trace their movements. 
All live dogs over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by 
a legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, by a microchip placed under the dog’s skin or if under 16 weeks of 
age a cage card may be used for official identification. The licensee must place a microchip under the dog’s skin of the 2 
dogs listed above or apply one of the other forms of identification. The licensee must ensure that all dogs have the correct 
type of official form of identification at all times. 
To be corrected by: 23-September-2022. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee documents the acquisition information for the adult dogs on APHIS 7005 (Record of Acquisition for Dogs). 
Only 4 adult dogs are listed on the form and the inspector counted 91 adult dogs during the inspection. Acquisition 
information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of animals during inspection and to properly

trace their movements. 
 
The licensee documents the acquisition information for puppies born at the facility on a cage card. Two litters of puppies 
had not been updated on the cage cards when the puppies were sold. Litter 31- 3 Goldendoodle puppies were sold but 
not marked on the cage card. Litter 22- 1 Bernedoodle puppy was sold but not marked on the cage card. Acquisition 
records of animals born at the premises must be accurate and kept up to date to ensure proper identification and allow 
APHIS officials to track the animal's movement. 
 
The facility shall make, keep, and maintain an approved method of documentation which fully and correctly disclose all 
information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or 
under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The facility 
must ensure all required acquisition information for each dog is properly and accurately documented at all times. 
 
To be corrected by: 19-September-2022. 
3.1(a)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There are 3 outdoor enclosures housing a total of 12 adult dogs where the dogs have dug large holes under flooring 
structures. 2 enclosures, the holes were dug under cement hog slat flooring and 1 enclosure had a hole dug below plastic 
flooring. The holes were large enough for the large breed dogs to fit their head and front legs below the flooring. Holes 
dug beneath flooring at severe angles into the ground could cause injury or even the death of a dog should the flooring 
collapse into the holes. 
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in

good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from 
entering. The facility must eliminate the holes dug in the enclosure to ensure the safety of the dogs. 
To be corrected by: 19-September-2022. 
3.1(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
At least 11 enclosures housing 44 adult dogs had significant buildup of cobwebs in their outdoor shelter. The facility 
representative stated these cobwebs were not present last week when he cleaned. The cobwebs were present in all 4 
corners of the shelters and at least 3 enclosures had cobwebs present in the top of the self feeder. Many cobwebs were 
still active with spiders present and dead insects in the webs. 
All surfaces of housing facilities must be cleaned and sanitized when necessary to satisfy generally accepted husbandry 
standards and practices to support the health of the dogs. The facility must clean and sanitize surfaces in the outdoor 
shelters on a schedule that prevents the buildup of cobwebs and pests (spiders and other insects). 
To be corrected by: 20-September-2022. 
3.6(a)(2)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The inspector observed 4 adult poodles running loose on the property. The facility representative was unaware of the 
dogs being out of their outdoor enclosure. They stated they have had some people dumping dogs on their property 
recently. When the inspector and facility representative went outside, the dogs were identified as the facility's dogs and he 
knew which pen they were from. All dogs went back into their enclosure at the time of inspection. The clips holding the 
gate to the enclosure seemed to have failed to hold the gate closed causing their escape. 
A primary enclosure must contain the dogs securely to ensure they are protected from various possible injuries. The

facility must ensure that all enclosures contain the dogs at all times. 
To be corrected by: This day forward. 
3.9(a) 
   
Feeding 
At least 3 outdoor enclosures housing a total of 14 adult dogs had caked dog kibble present in the self feeder. The 
accumulation of caked food in the corners of the feeder tray was scraped away with the inspector's finger nail. One 
enclosure housing 4 adult dogs had cobwebs with dead insects present in the top of the self feeder and a beetle was 
found in the tray in a chunk of kibble and dog hair. Dog food that is caked, deteriorating and/or contaminated by insects is 
not considered wholesome and palatable and may lead to reduced feed consumption, poor nutrition and poor body 
condition.  
Food must be uncontaminated, wholesome, palatable, and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain the normal 
condition and weight of the dog. The licensee must remove all contaminated, caked, and deteriorating food from the self-
feeders and ensure that all food remains uncontaminated and of good quality at all times. 
To be corrected by: 19-September-2022. 
 
This inspection was conducted with a facility representative and the exit interview was conducted with the licensee and 
facility representative. 
 
The licensee cancelled his USDA license in writing effective immediately during the exit interview.
